trustfund: TF020430-AUSTRIAN CONSULTANT TRUST FUND,TF022588-PHRD-TRANSPORT SECTOR II

abstracts.cdata!:
Despite the achievements of highway and
            railway institutional components, the project overall is
            rated marginally unsatisfactory. The railways ministry
            remained in default of legal/financial covenants, and the
            physical component of the Railway loan (the largest single
            original component) did not achieve its objectives. Some key
            lessons learned are as follows: A permanently reliable
            source of maintenance funding is the single most important
            factor determining the success of highway or railway
            operations. Fundamental institutional reforms in the
            implementing agency are required up-front as a pre-condition
            for project approval. Consultants acting as Engineer must
            have clearly stated responsibilities, including those
            satisfying reasonable governmental audit requirements.
            Highway contract administration needs to be significantly
            improved to avoid costly claims against the employer.
            Simplified construction administration should be adopted.
            The implementing agency's technical and contract
            administration capacity should be assessed at the time of
            appraisal. If necessary the Borrower's audit staff
            should be trained in Bank procurement audit procedures and
            standard bidding documents. Vehicle overloading must be
            effectively addressed to minimize damage to the network.
            Preparation of railway projects with an operational
            component must consider freight traffic issues within the
            context of an overall logistics chain. Effective action must
            be taken against defaults on loan covenants.
